Got a Question
Not all students at Abertay have entered straight from school.  Our students have come from wide and varied backgrounds
column2: some have come directly from school
column4: and some students have been away from education for some time.  We recognise a wide range of qualifications as suitable alternatives to the traditional entrance requirements outlined in this prospectus

column1: • A relevant SQA certificate or diploma or the BTEC equivalent;
• An appropriate grouping of SQA National Certificate Modules;
• Satisfactory performance on an approved Access course;
• Any other qualifications or grouped qualifications of appropriate standard;
Many of our courses allow the opportunity for potential students to complete an Honours degree over three years instead of the usual four years.  Opportunities exist for suitably qualified applicants
column2: for example with SQA Advanced Highers or GCE A-Levels
column3: to gain direct entry to year two of the appropriate course.

column1: Potential applicants who expect to obtain either a Higher National Certificate (HNC) or Higher National Diploma (HND) qualification may also be considered for direct entry to year two or three of an appropriate degree programme.  Further details on advanced entry to the later years of degree programmes can be obtained from the Student Recruitment Office.
Mature students are those who are 21 years of age or older at the time they start their studies
column2: and are an important part of the University.  Today more than a third of our student population fall into this category.  We value mature students because they are one of the most enthusiastic and motivated groups on campus.  They often act as an inspiration to their younger classmates who can benefit from their skills and experience.  You will find it useful to check the entrance requirements outlined in the prospectus though mature applicants will not necessarily have to offer traditional school examination passes in order to gain admission.  Indeed you may be accepted on the basis of a wide range of qualifications such as Access courses
column3: Higher National qualifications or BTEC qualifications.

column1: One of the possible pathways to higher education for students who do not have the traditional entrance requirements is a full time Access course.  Access courses are designed to provide a programme of study for mature students
column2: to equip you with the general skills required to make a success of your studies at university and to give you a foundation of knowledge of subjects specific to a certain degree area.  There is a wide range of such courses on offer in further education colleges and some universities.  Access courses are generally one year in length.

column1: This part-time course takes place during the evening to allow those in or out of work the opportunity to gain access to Higher Education. The AHEAD programme is designed to allow people from diverse backgrounds to develop a range of transferable skills in a supportive and friendly environment and gives students an opportunity to experience the teaching and learning environment within higher education firsthand. The aim of the programme is to enable students to develop the skills
column2: confidence and qualifications necessary to progress onto a programme of study in higher education. Ongoing guidance and support is built in to the programme to help students to make informed choices about their future options and choices after completing AHEAD.  In addition to providing guided personal study and new transferable skills
column3: successful completion will enable entry to a number of degree courses at the University.

column1: Who is it for?  Summer School is designed for new students who want to boost their confidence and be better prepared for starting university
column2: either because they have just missed the entrance requirements for their course
column3: or because the admissions tutor has recommended that a refresher course would be helpful.

column1: What happens?  Summer School is an intensive three-week course
column2: combining practice to improve your IT
column3: research and study skills with an introduction to topics you will cover in your first term.

column1: When is it?  Summer School runs for the three weeks leading up to the start of term.

How much does it cost?  Currently there is no fee for Summer School and the University is normally able to provide a bursary of at £30 a week.  We also try to provide free accommodation for students who do not live in commuting distance of Dundee.

What have previous Summer School students said about it?  "It helped me get back into the swing of studying again."  "I've made some great friends."  "I can be confident about starting my course now."
The University also provides access through Accreditation of Prior Learning (APL) or Accreditation of Prior Experiential Learning (APEL). Applicants for entry through these routes
column2: and students having completed an access course
column3: are dealt with on an individual basis.

column1: We make our offers of entry based on qualifications offered worldwide.  We consider a wide variety of alternative qualifications on an individual basis.  The following are examples of accepted in recent years:

column2: international applicants are expected to obtain a suitable Honours degree or equivalent.  More information on acceptable overseas qualifications is available from the Student Recruitment Office

column1:
English Language Requirements

All our programmes are taught and examined in English
column2: therefore students whose native language is not English must either obtain a satisfactory score in a recognised test of English language competency or produce other proof of English language proficiency.  For a list of acceptable English language qualifications please refer to the English Language pages of this prospectus.

column1: The University welcomes applications from students currently studying for qualifications such as Higher National Certificates (HNC) or Higher National Diplomas (HND) from colleges of further education.  In many cases
column2: such applicants are considered for direct entry to the later years of degree courses.   Information on the articulation routes available is also available on our website http://www.abertay.ac.uk/International/EU/EUArticulation.cfm?Key=003.006.001
enrolment to courses of the University is
column4: open to all those who have the ability to benefit from the opportunity.  All applications to the University will be considered on an equal basis in line with the University’s Equal Opportunities Policy.  The University will not discriminate on the grounds of age
